text: NaOH does not have a pH, but an aqueous solution of NaOH does. Water contains both H+ and OH- ions. Adding NaOH increases the concentration of OH- ions and decreases the concentration of H+ ions. But there are *always* some H+ ions present, so aqueous NaOH solutions have a pH, usually between 7 and 14.
question: How can NaOH have a pH scale?

text: Fluids exert pressure in all directions. So the parts of the fluid on the left (P1) of the highlighted region are exerting a pressure on the highlighted region _from the left_. They still exert a pressure in all directions, but the only part of this pressure that is relevant is the part that is pushing the highlighted region. So when the fluid flows from right to left, the parts of the fluid on the left (P1) still exert a pressure on the highlighted region from the left. Similarly, P2 always exerts a pressure from the right because it is on the right side of the highlighted region (the section we are interested in). Whether work done is negative or positive depends on which direction the fluid is flowing and whether the work done is helping the movement or hindering it. When the fluid is moving from left to right, work done to the right is positive (as it is in the same direction as the flow) and work done to the left is negative (as it hinders the flow). When the fluid is moving from right to left, work done to the left is positive and work done to the right is negative
question: Why the pressure P1 still acts to the right and P2 still acts to the left?

text: Way metabolism would be even more complicated. Just activating separating enzymes for separating signals would be consuming and robust for our brains and bodies to control. It would be energy and time-consuming and hard to switch from one to another. This way is cost-effective and time-efficient for our bodies. I will illustrate it with the example of fighting cancer. Although originally designed to inhibit a single kinase, several small molecule inhibitors target several, often related, kinases. When used to treat tumours bearing activating mutations in a single kinase, these 'promiscuous' inhibitors have shown clinical effectiveness and less toxicity than expected. This effect may stem from their capacity to inhibit several kinases in a signalling 'network'. However, another possibility is that these broad-spectrum inhibitors inhibit kinases that might be activated by subsequent mutations. Now the problem of 'complex signalling pathway' bothers researchers when choosing methodology on how to study pathways and molecules. how to use genetic manipulations to overcome these difficulties. Phenotypes generated using traditional 'knockout' techniques-which completely ablate expression of a signalling protein-represent the aggregate consequence of disrupting all functions of, and severing all communication facilitated by, that protein. In contrast, more refined 'knock-in' techniques-which insert a discrete mutation into only one region of a protein-allow controlled manipulation of specific protein functions and signal interconnections. having complex system is good because that way one signalling molecule (let's take cAMP) can shut down or turn on multiple other enzymes and cascades. That way body only makes an effort to produce the first initial second messenger. The job is done. cANP binds to many different kinases and initiates 7 different processes! Imagine if it was 'easy' and 1 molecule regulated one enzyme. The body would have to produce 7 different molecules (second messengers) for 7 different kinases.
question: Why can't the enzyme that performs the cellular response just be immediately activated, without the need of a series of conformational protein changes?

text: Concentration gradient is potential energy being converted into kientic energy. Actually, if moving dow the gradient - there is no additional energ needed, if going against - then you need additional energy. Potential energy is energy which every moelcule (object) has and potentially can convert into kinetic energy. That's why it is called potential energy. Potential energy is the latent energy in an object at rest. The actual potential energy of an object depends on its position relative to other objects. For example, a brick has more potential energy suspended off of a two-story building than it does resting on the ground. That's because the brick's relative position to the Earth gives it more energy. Two bricks next to each other don't give each other more energy though, because there is no force acting on them

text: Neurons are the most unique cells in our body. Some are extremely small, while others are very large. In general, neurons do not repair well. If several neurons were damaged, such as in a spinal cord injury, you already know the individual would be paralyzed and it is unlikely the individual would ever walk again. If a portion of a neuron is damaged, it may or may not be able to find and re-connect with itself. If the axon is damaged, the myelin cells such as Schwann cells form a tunnel to help direct the axon to the other portion. Never-the-less, even after several years, if you touch an area of your body that has a scar, you will realize that touch or feeling over that scar has changed and it is not as sensitive as it once was because the receptors and axons were damaged when the skin was damaged. Now, even though the skin is well healed, the nervous tissue has not healed and therefore the sense of touch is poor over that scar. Epithelial tissue and connective tissue heal well, but nervous tissue does not have the ability to divide and replace neurons that have been damaged so it does not heal well.
question: How would other neurons and cells react?

text: Homology is defined as the property of being descended from a common ancestor. This can apply to structures, DNA sequences, or even behaviors that can be traced back to an ancestor shared by two (or more) species. As one example, the fore limbs of all mammals (including: bat wings, whale flippers, primate arms, and the front legs of quadrupeds) are homologous - they all are variations on the front limbs of the first shrew-like mammals. Relative position within an organism is one very important piece of evidence for a structure being homologous. Another type of evidence is developmental - do the structures develop in the same way.
question: Why are homologous structures considered similar in structure?

text: Nonpolar molecules that repel the water molecules are said to be hydrophobic; molecules forming ionic or a hydrogen bond with the water molecule is said to be hydrophilic. This property of water was important for the evolution of life. Hydrophobic interaction plays the most critical role in the formation of the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane and the folding of proteins and nucleic acids; therefore, hydrophobic interaction is the foundation for the existence of life. A self-assembled monolayer (SAM) is a layer of organic molecules formed spontaneously on a solid substrate. One end of the organic molecule binds to the solid surface via a covalent bond while the other endpoints outwards. Because the exposed end of the SAM determines the surface properties of the SAM modified substrate, we can alter a hydrophobic surface (a surface that expels water) into a hydrophilic surface (a surface that attracts water) by carefully selecting the SAM forming molecules.
question: What determines if something is hydrophobic or hydrophilic?

text: Light is the same entity whether it be on earth, other planets, the sun, or millions of light years away in distant space. Light itself can be thought of as being composed of massless 'particles' called photons which have both particle and wavelike properties. It has what is known as a wave-particle duality. A good demonstration of this is Thomas Young's double slit experiment. Basically he placed a plate in front of screen with two slits (or holes) in the plate which allowed light to pass through and would be detected on the screen behind. The critical aspect was how wide he made the slits. If you make the slits wide light passes straight through and hits the areas of the screen directly opposite of the slits. This is light behaving as a particle. Now if you made the slits super narrow you observe bands of light with different intensity on the screen separated by dark spaces. The bands corresponding to places where light acting as a wave interacted with itself constructively and the dark spaces where it interacted with itself destructively. This is known as interference and its something only waves can perform. Now since he used the same light and observed both wave and particle phenomenon, we can assume that light has both a wave and particle nature to it depending on the situation. Hope that helps.
question: Is it in the form of particles or waves?

text: Genes are found on strands of DNA, they are not themselves a strand of DNA. A gene is a sequence of base pairs that code for a specific protein, not a specific phenotypic trait as such. The various proteins interact in very complex ways to form traits. So, genes do not, strictly speaking, code for phenotypic traits. However, a specific trait might be reliant on the protein produced by one gene for some key aspect of its nature. So, while we might often say the gene for this or that trait, what is more accurate is saying the gene for the protein is involved in this or that trait. Genes, in fact, tend to be involved in multiple phenotypic traits because the protein they code for can be used in a variety of ways. Alleles are variations of genes, but they may or may not produce observable differences in some phenotypic trait. The reason is that proteins tend to be very large molecules and so a few minor changes here or there in their structure may or may not have much of an effect on their functions. So, some alleles produce proteins that produce pretty much identical phenotypic traits. Also, remember that some amino acids can be coded for by more than one codon, so some alleles merely contain different ways of coding for the same protein. But, obviously, some alleles, even with minor changes, can produce proteins that lead to significantly different traits. Eye color is not a good example because there are many genes involved in that (perhaps as many as 16 genes)
question: Are alleles just variations of a gene that code for the same trait but with physical differences?

text: A v-shape ('bent') shape occurs when an atom has 3 attached groups, with one of those groups being a lone pair. It also occurs when an atom has 4 attached groups and 2 of those groups are lone pairs. Be careful though, these shapes are called the same name, but they have different bond angles. A general chem class might require that you know 1 lone pair = less than 120 degrees, 2 lone pairs = less than 109.5 degrees. Also, It is possible for an atom to have 5 or even 6 groups attached to it (these cases are called expanded octets), such as Phosphorus pentachloride (PCl5) or sulfur hexafluoride (SF6).
question: Species have lone pairs molecular geometry can only be v-shaped or trigonal pyramid?

text: During the production of reproductive cells, chromosomes of the same type (except for X & Y in the case of chromosomally typically males) line up and exchange sections of their genetic code. If the chromosomes are not lined up perfectly during this process the codes may be reversed, or one may end up with two copies of a small section of DNA while the other gets none. Mutations that start here are often called crossing over errors. These mutations are particularly important because they are automatically germline mutations (able to be passed down to future generations). There are other possible sources of mutations, but most of these will be somatic mutations (not able to be passed to future generations).
question: Why do genetic mutations still exist in the gene pool?

text: Semipermeable and selectively permeable can be slightly different in meaning, though this usage is not consistent. Semipermeable is typically used as an overall term for membranes that only allow some molecules to pass through - in some cases this is used exclusively for selection based on molecule (or ion) size. Selectively permeable just means that some molecules can pass through the membrane based on their properties, but most molecules or ions can not pass through the membrane. Different semipermeable membranes may let different size molecules pass through - an example of this is dialysis membranes (or tubing), which can be made with pore sizes that will allow small macromolecules (e.g. proteins) to pass through while restricting larger macromolecules.

Secondary active transport means that, rather than directly using ATP to power the movement of compounds across the membrane, proteins like symporters and antiporters use the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient. The electrochemical gradient is the combined "push" due to concentration and charge differences across the membrane.

text: The tree of life is a metaphor for the fact that all life on earth is evolutionarily related, somewhat like a huge version of a human family tree. The tree really has nothing to do with physical characteristics such as fur or number of legs. Because evolution allows lineages to change physiologically and anatomically, many pairs of species on earth are quite different. When we look at two species whose members outwardly appear somewhat similar, this is a clue that they share a recent common ancestor. For example, dogs and horses are biologically separate lineages, however they are similar enough (four legs, fur) that it is highly likely that the two lineages split more recently, such as two first cousins who's most recent common ancestor was a grandparent. When we talk about a biological common ancestor, we really mean an ancestral species consisting of many individuals. A "grandparent population" that split and became two separate populations, which persisted into becoming modern day dogs and horses. On the other hand, dogs and mosquitoes are very different, which is a clue that their common ancestor diverged into the two lineages a very long time ago, like two distant cousins sharing a great great great great great great grandparent. This ancestral species probably outwardly looked nothing like either a dog or a mosquito. So the whole idea of the tree of life is to convey the idea that all living species, including dogs, horses, and mosquitoes are related, even though some are more closely related than others.
question: How would dogs and horses be listed?

The amino group of one amino acid reacts with the carboxylic acid group of another, with the elimination of water. text: In this theory, RNA came first. RNA can do everything it needs to do: selfreproduce, catalyze reactions, regulate - all of which it still does today to different degrees. Since RNA is chemically relatively simple and doesn't have many different structural elements (only its 4 bases and its repeating backbone), it could be produced by natural chemical processes on some kind of matrix (which helps keeping the molecules in place so that they can get larger and larger till RNA happens). Metallic clay in shallow water is a great contender for that matrix. This is pretty uncontroversial amongst proponents of Abiogenesis, but after that point scholars are divided on what happened next - did DNA come next as more stable storage medium of information (this is most likely since DNA and RNA are closely related chemically and we know for a fact that RNA can handle DNA) or did RNA develop the ability to make proteins (also not impossible since we know for a fact that amino acids can be made by chemical processes not involving life and RNA is today heavily involved in making proteins). Once you have all three, no matter what comes first after RNA, the next threshold of complexity, the first cell, is a comparatively easy step.
question: Did RNA exist before cells?

text: An ionic bond or a covalent bond, the metal atoms want to share electrons to gain a eight electrons in their valence ring or shell. They are mostly loosely bound because otherwise, they wouldn't have the metallic characteristics. it's just another constant in nature; metals just bond that way. text: In eukaryotes, free ribosome's actually assemble around the mRNA then will begin reading the code. Fairly early on a certain sequence in the RNA may be recognised which causes the whole translation process to halt while the mRNA-ribosome complex is all transferred to the endoplasmic reticulum, translation will then begin again with the growing polypeptide chain entering the ER lumen. The process is known as cotranslational localisation. Generally speaking, proteins that are destined for lysosomes, membranes or to be secreted from the cell are made on the RER. Once the mRNA molecule is exported from the nucleus and is recognized by a ribosome, it will be translated initially in the cytosol. However, if the protein needs to be targeted to the ER, the first 5 to 30 amino acids will encode what's called 'Signal Peptide', which is a structure recognized by a protein called 'Signal Recognition Particle' (SRP). SRP binds signal peptide and pauses translation. SRP then facilitates docking of the ribosome to the Rough ER, after which signal peptide is cleaved off of the protein and translation continues into the lumen of the Rough ER.
question: What dictates whether or not a strand of mRNA attaches to a free-floating ribosome?

text: the geometry of the molecule is important as well, perhaps more important in certain cases. In the case of SiF4, the dipole moment of each Si-F bond will cancel each other out, as it is of tetrahedral geometry. A good example is carbon dioxide (non-polar) vs formaldehyde (polar). The dipole moment along each C=O bond in CO2 will cancel each other out since the molecule is linear. However, the dipole moment of the C=O bond and each C-H bond in CH2O will reinforce each other (trigonal planar geometry about the carbon center, with smaller H-C-H angle and larger O-C-H angles). Different texts will give different numbers. A difference in electronegativity of 1.7 means there is 50% ionic character in the bond, that's the most common number I've seen. I've also seen 2.0 given. That said it isn't foolproof, in SiF4 there is a difference in electronegativity of 2.08 and it behaves like a non polar covalent molecule would.
question: Is there an exact number that makes it polar or nonpolar?

text: For all proteins mRNA first binds to a 'free' ribosome (in the cytosol, not bound to the ER). Proteins that are synthesized on the rough ER (RER) are made by ribosomes that *temporarily* attach to the surface of the RER. Those ribosomes are tethered to the ER by the growing polypeptide, which is inserted into the RER membrane. This insertion typically happens based on a sequence at the N-terminus (beginning) of some proteins called the 'signal sequence'. This sequence stops protein synthesis until the peptide and ribosome are associated with the RER. The proteins that are made at the RER end up either remaining inserted into the RER membrane or within the lumen of the RER. In either case they are typically further processed and sent elsewhere inside (or outside) the cell. Once the protein is completed it usually separates from the ribosome, which is then (usually) no longer connected to the ER. if you broke the machinery that recognizes the signal sequence, then RER synthesized proteins would stop being made. However, if you somehow just 'knocked' the ribosomes off the RER, new ribosomes with their signal sequence containing proteins would just rebind and start translating. Other proteins are synthesized on 'free' ribosomes that never attach to the ER. Synthesis of these proteins would not be directly affected.
question: Do cells can still synthesize the protein?

text: If you want to start off with a guess for one of your mesh currents, you can do that. I recommend you start with that mesh, and then use the same direction for all the rest. Your guess (assuming it is correct) will earn you a + sign for that mesh current. The Mesh Current Method is set up as a robotic recipe for solving circuits, with the emphasis on consistency and getting the signs correct. It does not need a good guess to get the right answer. This won't take too long: solve your circuit two ways, with your guess, and with all clockwise. Notice how you get a few sign changes in the set of equations that emerge. And notice if it is easier or harder to write the terms where two mesh currents flow in one element.
question: Should we continue with our guess or let it go and use the clockwise direction for all?

text: Electrons are not made up of anything smaller. They are just electrons. Protons and neutrons are made up of smaller particles called quarks. Protons and neutrons are made up of different mixtures of quarks, so they have different properties. Yes, all protons, electrons and neutrons are the same. Except for mass (how much something 'weighs'), most of the physical and chemical properties of atoms are caused by the very complicated ways in which their electromagnetic fields interact at a microscopic level. Thus, when you mix different kinds of atoms together, you get complicated changes in their electromagnetic fields. Sometimes these are major changes, sometimes these are minor changes. When oxygen and hydrogen mix together to make water, they release a tremendous amount of energy, and you wind up with two atoms of hydrogen being held (we call that 'bonded') to one atom of oxygen. You have the same atoms, but the amount of energy they have now is much, much less and their electrical fields have radically changed. Thus, water is not much like hydrogen or oxygen, but has its own properties. A better analogy than mixing paint is mixing wheat, water, and oil (and a few minor ingredients). Think of all the things you can make with just these three things depending on how much of each you use and how you put them together. You can get dough, biscuits, noodles, pudding, breakfast cereal, glue, gravy, sauces, a variety of wheat beers, farina, etc. It all depends on how much of the components you use and just how you go about putting them together. Much the same thing happens at the microscopic level -- what you get depends on how much you have of a few basic 'ingredients' and how you go about putting them together.
question: What are these 'parts' made out of? why changing the number of 'parts' that are supposedly the same exact things changes hydrogen into water for example?

text: Life is an emergent property -- that means a property held by the whole that is not held by the parts. The chemicals of which life is composed are neither alive nor dead, but collectively they can have the properties we call life. Emergent properties are not at all unusual. For example, cotton fibers are quite easily pulled apart, but twisted together and woven into cloth they take on an emergent property of being quite strong. Individual drops of water do not have the property of 'storm' but a lot of water can. And so it is with life. Life is an emergent property that a vast number of chemicals can sometimes take on, though the individual chemicals do not have this property.
question: What makes human living not dead,like other chemicals?

Sodium lost an electron, so it is now a Sodium 1+ ion, and Chlorine gained an electron, so it is now a Chloride 1- ion. The opposite charges attract, so then it becomes NaCl with a charge of zero.

text: Yes, you would need a molecule with a steric number of 3, but is bonded to only two atoms. An example of that would be sulfur dioxide or ozone. So if the molecule is bent then it will be so in two scenarios. Either with a steric number of 3 giving the central atom sp2 hybridization making it electronically trigonal planar, but physically bent (like in the above examples). Or with a steric number of 4 giving the central atom sp3 hybridization making it electronically tetrahedral, but physically bent (like with water). In the trigonal planar one, the electron groups are ideally 120 degrees apart from each other. But because of the lone pair making it bent, the bond angle will be slightly less for the two atoms bonded to the central carbon. Maybe around 119 degrees. In the tetrahedral one, the electrons groups are ideally 109.5 degrees apart from each other. The lone pairs will decrease that making it somewhere between 107-109 degrees between the two atoms bonded to the central atom.
question: When we do have a bent molecular geometry for an atom, how do we find out the angle degrees?
